item.title: Ticket #569 (Percent sign (%) in title leads to unusable permalinks) updated
item.dc:creator: majelbstoat
item.description: On second thoughts, urlencoding everything in the path could break plugins that do rewrite rules checking. This new patch only encodes '%' to '%25', which still fixes the non-followable permalinks problem, without potentially causing problems elsewhere.

item.description: Most of the wp_specialchars calls in that function can be removed since the filters for those elements take care of specialchars.

item.description: Don't specialchar user description on save. fixes #3069

item.title: Ticket #3069 (User description (profile) is stored in database html entity encoded) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
Do we need to do any database upgrade on this?

Where are we kses's the profile - a quick search lead me to nothing.

item.title: Ticket #3069 (User description (profile) is stored in database html entity encoded) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status changed

Patch removes call to wp_specialchars();

This will need a security check to make sure that wp_specialchars() call wasn't protecting against script injection. It's already kses'd via filters, however.

item.title: no_entity_encode_user_description.diff attached to Ticket #3069
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: Patch for /trunk/

item.title: Ticket #3069 (User description (profile) is stored in database html entity encoded) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description: The user description (profile) is stored in the database encoded into html entities. This necessitates extra work if you actually want to display the user description on the site somewhere, like on their author page, and have things like links work.

item.description: so what's the last word? Should people be using 4106 or the one in the attachments? BTW thx for taking care of this problem!

item.title: Ticket #2721 (Add filter for wp-db query) updated
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: A number of queries are run before plugins are loaded. The options table is hit several times, for example. Those queries couldn't be altered by a plugin. This reduces the utility of a filter a bit. A filter might still be worthwhile, but most folks who want to tweak wp-db create a new db class that inherits from wpdb and replaces methods it wants to change.

item.title: Ticket #2721 (Add filter for wp-db query) updated
item.dc:creator: filosofo
item.description:
I just attached another patch that will apply the filter only if apply_filters is loaded, just in case someone should call wp-db.php before then.

How about that? This would be a really helpful feature to have.

item.title: wp-db.2.diff attached to Ticket #2721
item.dc:creator: filosofo
